As I've mentioned in other posts, I took a year off KSP and have been getting back into the game over the past few weeks.

Now I have access to larger tanks and engines, I find that the designs I used to use arent working with the new aerodynamics in the updated game.

Every time I try and build a larger rocket, it starts to wobble / oscillate like mad. Any tips for making things more sturdy, or is the problem more to do with velocity low in the atmosphere?

Cheers 

Clipper

struts, struts and more stuts lol

 

one thing i also do sometimes is to right click on your engines and limit the gimble to about 25%

"Spamming struts" is not usually helpful.  A well-placed strut can do wonders.

However, we really need to see screenshots.  The answer to "how can I not wobble too much" is "don't build wobbly rockets."    Ask a general question, get a general answer.

To help you, we need to see what you're building.  If you can post a screenshot of a ship that's giving you trouble, we can offer concrete suggestions on what's wrong with it and how you can solve the problem.

General rule-of-thumb tips:

  • Try not to get too tall and skinny.  (Which is tricky, because for better aero you want tall and skinny.)
  • Avoid having lots and lots of parts in a vertical stack.  Have a smaller number of bigger parts.
  • If you have to have any small, in-line stack parts (like batteries), put 'em up on the top of the stack, not right in the middle.
  • Reduce the gimbal on your engines if you have SAS turned on.  As your ship gets longer, on the one hand it becomes weaker against wobble, whereas on the other hand your engine gimbal gets a bigger lever arm and is stronger to cause wobble.  As long as you have an aerodynamically stable ship, you don't need much gimbal-- try turning it down to 25% or 30%.
  • If you have radially-attached boosters, you need struts to stabilize them.  You don't need a lot, but you do need at least one (well-placed) strut per each.

33 minutes ago, DD_bwest said:

i once saw someone place struts under an engines shroud connecting the decouple to the engine.   do you know if these would actually do anything? i havent tried it

I doubt that would do much.  Really poor leverage for the strut.  Placement is everything-- it's all about maximizing the lever arm.

Here's a pretty good discussion about how strut placement works, and what the difference is between effective and ineffective placement:

It's nice, because it's got plenty of pictures:  the OP is trying to strengthen the wings on a plane, is using struts to try to do that, but they're not helping.  He gives pictures.  Here's my particular post within that thread, explaining how struts work and how you should place them for maximum effect:

Then he tries changing the strut placement to follow the advice... and suddenly his plane's a whole lot stronger, with much fewer struts!

On 4/13/2016 at 4:31 PM, drtricky said:

I'm impressed! I put 4 3 struts as long as possible on the wing of that fighter, and it was able to pull out of a 400 m/s dive at 2000 m, totaling over 28.5 gees! Never before had it been able to do that, especially with 10 tons of weaponry!

...anyway, struts are great, but onlyif they're placed correctly.  One single strut placed right can make a world of difference.  A whole bunch of struts placed wrong will accomplish nothing but add weight and drag.

 

37 minutes ago, Kurld said:

If you're not averse to mods, try Kerbal Joint Reinforcement.

It's certainly possible to do that.  However, my own advice would be, I'd strongly recommend not using KJR.  It's a cure worse than the disease, IMO.  Here's my rant on the subject, taken from the above-linked thread, since any time the topic of wobbling rockets comes up, someone always suggests KJR.  In a spoiler section so folks who aren't interested in the rant don't have to wade through it.

Spoiler

Why I think KJR is overused:

I view the wobbliness of stock parts as a feature, not a bug.  It's not just that I enjoy the technical challenge of building a craft that stands up against all sorts of engineering challenges (including wobbliness).  It's also that wobbles are the game's way of telling you that there's a problem with your design.

I routinely build all sorts of craft, including big 'uns that are hundreds of tons.  And they get along fine without KJR, no wobble.  It just takes some attention to design.  I do use struts, but only minimally; typically, one strut per radial booster is about the limit.  I don't fly planes a lot, but on those occasions when I fly big ones, a couple of struts to reinforce the wings generally does the trick.   (And I mean literally "a couple", as in "two", not "a bunch").

If you just go straight to KJR, you deprive yourself of the chance to learn how to design craft that don't need it.  Including big ones.

Also, there's a potentially more insidious problem:  a craft that's unwieldy enough to wobble a lot without KJR help is also likely to run into other flight problems as well, and using KJR to gloss over those problems has the potential to be like taking an aspirin for that nagging pain in your chest-- it would be better to find out what the pain is and fix the root cause.  I've seen Gameplay Questions posts from people who build a huge unwieldy monstrosity, then use KJR to stiffen it up... and then find out that it can't fly because it's horribly unstable, or some similar problem associated with the unwieldiness of the design.  "Too wobbly" can also be a warning sign that you're making your craft a lot bigger than it actually needs to be.

9 hours ago, Snark said:

However, we really need to see screenshots.  The answer to "how can I not wobble too much" is "don't build wobbly rockets."    Ask a general question, get a general answer.

Very true!  I usually think to ask advice on matters after I've switched from laptop to tablet, hence lack of screenshots.  I'll add some if the general advice still leaves me wobbling

I reckon the main issue is the way I've unlocked the tech tree so far. I'm re-playing Science Mode and I've skimped on unlocking the large volume fuel tanks in favour of other goodies.  Using several smaller tanks of a given radius is obviously far less effective than I realised, compared to one big tank.

One additional question about struts - When I want to use a vertical strut to add rigidity, to avoid clipping I'll add a modular girder then attach a strut from the girder to the main body of the rocket (so the girder, strut and rocket form a nice triangle). I'm finding that they look just the way I want them in the VAB, but once out on the launchpad the struts appear as short stubs heading off in random directions.  Does that a) not matter as the game still knows where they "really" are or b) they no longer work as the game sees them as broken little stubs rather than complete struts? 

Apologies for the lack of screenshots, I'll remedy that later today.

Thanks for the advice

PS Of course everyone has their own way of playing, but for me I always play mod free for the "pure" KSP experience!

Edited August 27, 2016 by Clipperride
Added PS and expanded explanation to try and make up for the lack of screenshots.

Results - I removed all the additional girders and struts I'd added to try and make the rocket rigid (so the only struts remaining were between radial tanks (with engines) and the main stack) and reduced the gimbal range on the first stage to 25%. Now she flies pretty darn straight with only a slight roll that is easily cancelled out.

Thanks for the tip!  The only other problem I encountered was when trying to dock the lander with the command module.  A docking port on both, rather than just the CM, sorted that out (it's amazing how many times I forget to add the second port!?!)!  Luckily It was only a test flight to Munar distance so after a quick bit of EVA, all were home in time for tea and medals.

@Snark I respect your opinion about KJR, but I disagree. I think the wobbliness is one of the major "flaws" of the game.. it's completely overblown (after all, real rockets do wobble a little) and an accidental result of the way the game engine handles collisions/part attachment. A properly designed rocket should not require MOAR STRUTS (or even a few carefully placed ones) to achieve stable flight. To me, that seems absurd.

Can you abuse KJR?  Sure I suppose so. I don't care. Knock yourself out if you want to do that. Have fun.

Wobbly rockets (even the most basic of designs) are not fun, for me anyways.
